hedline.hl1: Actors' Strike Dragging On As Talks Break Down

abstract.p: Thirteen days of negotiations between representatives of advertisers and actors on strike break down as strike approaches end of its fifth month; negotiators for Screen Actors Guild and American Federation of Television and Radio Artists reject 90-day cooling off period in which actors could return to work under their 1997 contract (M)

block.p: Thirteen days of negotiations between representatives of advertisers and actors on strike broke down yesterday as the strike approached the end of its fifth month.

The day ended with negotiators for the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists rejecting a 90-day cooling off period in which actors could return to work under their 1997 contract, said Greg Krizman, a spokesman for S.A.G.
Thirteen days of negotiations between representatives of advertisers and actors on strike broke down yesterday as the strike approached the end of its fifth month.

The day ended with negotiators for the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists rejecting a 90-day cooling off period in which actors could return to work under their 1997 contract, said Greg Krizman, a spokesman for S.A.G.

John A. McGuinn, a lawyer representing advertisers, said industry negotiators initially opposed the cooling-off period but then accepted it, going so far as to offer to pay actors retroactively under the new scale for work during the period once a contract was reached. ''I'm really, really disappointed,'' Mr. McGuinn said. ''I thought a deal was within range.''

Negotiators, who were meeting in New York, said talks broke down over two main issues: whether the new contract would cover work on the Internet and how much actors would be paid for commercials shown on cable television.

The sides have been at odds over how actors will be paid for advertisements shown on television. Actors have been pushing to expand a system used for network commercials known as pay-for-play, in which they are paid each time a commercial is broadcast. Advertisers had been seeking a flat-fee arrangement like the one used on cable networks.

The two sides have bridged that gap, agreeing to continue pay-for-play on networks and extending the system of a flat fee for cable. But the two sides are still trying to agree on pay scales for actors' work on cable. Advertisers have proposed a tiered payment system over three years starting at $1,250 for a 13-week cycle the first year of the contract and increasing to $1,850 by the third year. That is well below the $2,500 being sought by the unions for the third year.
The negotiating committee for the unions was meeting into the evening to determine the next step, Mr. Krizman said. He said actors remained steadfast in their resolve.

''Our members have known since day one what is at stake here, and it's basically the survival of middle-class actors,'' Mr. Krizman said. ''Middle-class actors won't be able to survive under the terms that they have offered.''
The talks broke down late in the day after a rally at the Crowne Plaza Hotel in Manhattan featuring several celebrities, including Tim Robbins, Susan Sarandon, Julia Roberts and Richard Dreyfus.
